intro: Galium adhaerens, commonly known as sticky willow or bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems covered in fine, sticky hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, oval-shaped, and have a slightly hairy texture. Galium adhaerens thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
